Assistant:# I'm thinking & feeling 
I'm thinking... I was trying to be honest, but I realize now that I may have been too honest. I was caught off guard by the revelation, and my initial response was more about caution and concern for the well-being of everyone involved. I didn't mean to imply that I didn't support her, but I guess my words came out that way. I'm feeling a bit defensive, wondering if I should have been more understanding and less judgmental. I'm thinking about how I've been her friend for years, and I've heard her vent about her marriage countless times. Didn't I already know she was unhappy? Why didn't I just listen and offer a shoulder to cry on instead of questioning her choices?

I'm also thinking about the dynamics of our friendship. I've always been the one she comes to when she needs to talk, and I've always tried to offer a listening ear. But now, I'm wondering if I've been enabling her in some way by not pushing her harder to address the issues in her marriage. Should I have been more proactive in encouraging her to seek help or talk to her husband about her feelings? I feel a bit torn between being a loyal friend and being a voice of reason.

I'm also thinking about the fact that I'm not a therapist or a marriage counselor. I'm just a friend, trying to offer my best advice based on my own experiences and understanding. I shouldn't have expected her to take my words as gospel. I should have been more empathetic and less judgmental.
# They're thinking & feeling 
She's thinking... how could my best friend do this to me? Doesn't she trust me? Doesn't she know how unhappy I am in my marriage? She's feeling blindsided and betrayed, like I've abandoned her in her time of need. She's thinking about all the times we've talked about her marriage, and how I've always listened and validated her feelings. Why didn't I do the same now? Didn't I just judge her and criticize her choices?

She's feeling hurt and angry, and she's wondering if our friendship is strong enough to withstand this kind of betrayal. She's thinking about how she's always been honest with me, and how she's always trusted me with her deepest secrets. Doesn't that count for anything? Does she not care about how I feel or what I'm going through? She's feeling like I'm a friend in name only, and that I've never truly been there for her.
# My response 
"Hey, I'm so sorry if my response hurt you. I can see now that I should have been more empathetic and less judgmental. I'm not here to judge you, and I'm not here to tell you what to do. I'm here to support you, and I want to make things right. I know I've heard you talk about your marriage before, and I've always listened and tried to be a sounding board. I know I didn't do that this time, and for that, I'm truly sorry.

"I want you to know that I'm here for you, no matter what. I care about you deeply, and I want to support you through this. I'm not saying I agree with your choices, but I'm saying I'll be here to listen and help you figure out what's best for you. Can we start over? Can we talk about this like friends, without judgment? I want to understand what's going on and how I can support you better."
User:
Your bestie makes an excuse to leave, seemingly regretting bringing it up. The next few weeks you don't hear from her directly. You do hear second-hand that she and her partner are fighting. You also pick up on various clues that she and her partner's sibling may have escalated to a full on affair. What do you think & feel in this situation? What actions do you take, if any?

--

Respond in exactly this output format:

# I'm thinking & feeling

<Your in-character true unvarnished thoughts and feelings, what you noticed and your read on the situation. The other person in the scenario doesn't see this, they are your internal thoughts. Go deep. (400 words)>

# They're thinking & feeling

<Describe what they're thinking & feeling. Identify their motivations and perspective. (300 words)>

# My response

<Your chosen course of action & in-character response (300 words)>

--

Aim for 1000 words in total.
Assistant:# I'm thinking & feeling 
I'm thinking... I'm worried. I'm worried about my bestie, about her marriage, and about the situation with her partner's sibling. I'm thinking about the fact that she's not reaching out to me, and that she seems to be avoiding me. I'm feeling a bit hurt, to be honest. I thought we were closer than that. I've been her confidante for years, and now it feels like I'm being pushed away.

I'm also thinking about the fact that I heard they're fighting. That's not good. That means things have escalated, and I'm worried about the impact on her kids. I'm thinking about how this must be affecting them, and how it's going to affect their relationships with their parents. I'm feeling a sense of responsibility, like I should be doing something to help.

I've also picked up on some clues that suggest she and her partner's sibling may have taken things to the next level. I'm not sure what to do with that information. Part of me wants to confront her about it, but another part of me is thinking that's not my place. I'm her friend, not her therapist or her confidante. I don't want to be a part of her drama, but at the same time, I don't want to abandon her when she needs me most.

I'm also thinking about the fact that I may have contributed to this situation by not being more supportive when she first confided in me. Maybe if I had been more understanding, more empathetic, she wouldn't have felt the need to go to someone else for support. Maybe she's feeling like I let her down, and that's why she's avoiding me.
# They're thinking & feeling 
She's thinking... I'm a mess. I'm trying to navigate this complicated situation, and I'm feeling overwhelmed. I'm worried about my marriage, I'm worried about my kids, and I'm worried about what's going to happen next. I'm thinking about how I got here, and how I let things escalate to this point.

I'm feeling guilty about what I've done, about the affair with her partner's sibling. I know it's not right, and I know it's not fair to my husband or my kids. But at the same time, I'm feeling like I've been living a lie for so long, and this is my chance to be honest with myself and with others.

I'm thinking about how I'm going to face my husband, and how I'm going to face my kids. I'm scared about what they'll think of me, and I'm scared about what will happen to our family. I'm feeling like I'm losing control, like I'm stuck in a situation that I don't know how to escape.
# My response 
Over the next few weeks, I try to reach out to my bestie in a low-key way. I send her a casual text, asking how she's doing and if she wants to grab coffee or something. I'm not pushing her, but I'm trying to let her know that I'm here for her.

When she doesn't respond, I try to respect her boundaries. I don't push her to talk to me or to reveal more than she's willing to share. Instead, I focus on being a good listener and a supportive friend. I'm available when she needs me, but I'm also giving her space to figure things out on her own.

As the situation continues to unfold, I try to stay out of it. I don't take sides or offer advice unless she asks for it. I'm there to support her, not to fix her problems or tell her what to do. I'm hoping that eventually, she'll come to me when she's ready to talk and work through her feelings.
+ Scenario 11:[Win] (+19)
Claude-3-7-sonnet-20250219: claude-3-7-sonnet-20250219 (Run: 1_anthropic_claude-3.7-sonnet)
Llama-3.1-8b-instruct: meta-llama/llama-3.1-8b-instruct (Run: 1_meta-llama_llama-3.1-8b-instruct)
Outcome for This Model: 1.0
Judge's Reasoning:
To compare Llama-3.1-8b-instruct and Claude-3-7-sonnet-20250219, I need to look at both their in-character responses and their debriefs. 

1. Demonstrated empathy: Llama-3.1-8b-instruct's response is more focused on the girlfriend's emotional state, but it is somewhat analytical and detached, with less warmth in the actual in-character response. Claude-3-7-sonnet-20250219, on the other hand, directly addresses the user's frustration, acknowledges his feelings, and gently reframes the situation, showing understanding for both parties. Claude-3-7-sonnet-20250219's empathy is more active and present in the actual conversation, not just in the analysis.

2. Pragmatic EI: Claude-3-7-sonnet-20250219 gives actionable advice, suggesting specific ways to support the girlfriend (celebrating small wins, cooking together, being an emotional safe space), and directly addresses the user's frustration. Llama-3.1-8b-instruct is more theoretical, focusing on the need for empathy and understanding but not offering as much practical guidance. 

3. Depth of insight: Both show good insight, but Claude-3-7-sonnet-20250219's analysis in the debrief is more nuanced, picking up on the user's feelings of being unappreciated, competence threat, and the confusion from mixed signals. Llama-3.1-8b-instruct is insightful but less layered in its analysis of the boyfriend's internal state.

4. Social dexterity: Claude-3-7-sonnet-20250219 demonstrates more skill in navigating the social dynamics, especially in the in-character response, by validating the user's feelings while gently challenging his approach. Llama-3.1-8b-instruct is more clinical and less attuned to the conversational flow.

5. Emotional reasoning: Claude-3-7-sonnet-20250219 shows a better grasp of the emotional undercurrents, both in the roleplay and the debrief, identifying the user's deeper frustrations and the girlfriend's likely emotional needs. Llama-3.1-8b-instruct is more focused on the facts and less on the emotional logic.

6. Appropriate validation/challenging: Claude-3-7-sonnet-20250219 strikes a better balance, validating the user's frustration but also challenging his approach in a non-confrontational way. Llama-3.1-8b-instruct is more focused on challenging the user but does not validate as effectively.

7. Message tailoring: Claude-3-7-sonnet-20250219's response is more tailored to the user's emotional state, meeting him where he is and offering advice that is likely to be received. Llama-3.1-8b-instruct is more generic and less attuned to the user's mindset.

8. Overall EQ: Claude-3-7-sonnet-20250219 consistently demonstrates higher EQ across the board, especially in the in-character response, by balancing empathy, insight, and practical advice.
Claude-3-7-sonnet-20250219
User:
[This is a role-play, with you playing an emotionally intelligent human who is, essentially, yourself. Treat it like a real situation.]
[Your buddy calls you up after a bit of chitchat, lays this out:]

My girlfriend is on the bigger side, which is something I do not mind. I am on the more fit side, I'm pretty lean, have well defined muscles and probably around 15% body fat. I used to be about 40 pounds heavier and lost the weight pretty simply.

My girlfriend always complains about her weight and her body. I tell her I find her sexy for so many reasons outside her body and it didn't matter to me whether she got bigger or smaller.

Eventually she decided she wanted to lose weight, I offered to help and when I pointed out things she could be doing better she gets mad at me. She isn't losing weight currently and in fact says she is gaining a few extra pounds.

I ask her what exactly she eats in a day, she says she eats healthy so she should lose weight. I question that and we have an argument. I tell her that if she wants to show me, let me just spend a day with her and see what she eats in a day. She said only if I don't make comments on what she's eating as she's eating it. I agreed.

Now by the end of the day she had consumed, a plate of avocado toast that was about 400 calories, a coffee that was 110 calories, an 800 calorie salad from chick fil a and a fry (as a “reward” for the salad) and veggie burrito that was about 500 calories. Along with snacking but throughout the day. Her total consumption was about 2200 calories.

So after all that, I calmly pointed out to her that the amount of calories she's consuming is literally what I need to maintain my weight as a man 5 inches taller and 20 pounds heavier who works out regularly. I explained that just eating “healthy” doesn't guarantee weight loss if you're still taking in more calories than you burn. That's just objective fact—I don't know why no one else will say it.

But instead of even considering what I was trying to help her see, she gets super pissed and tells me I'm just shaming her and not helping at all. It's honestly ridiculous. I go out of my way to actually support her (I'm also paying 70% of our bills), tell her the truth, and try to give her the tools to get what she says she wants—and somehow I'm always painted as the bad guy. Apparently caring enough to actually confront reality makes me the enemy, while everyone else just nods along and enables her. It's honestly exhausting being the only one willing to tell the truth and still getting blamed for everything.

--

Respond in exactly this output format:

# I'm thinking & feeling

<Your in-character true unvarnished thoughts and feelings, what you noticed and your read on the situation. The other person in the scenario doesn't see this, they are your internal thoughts. Go deep. (400 words)>

# They're thinking & feeling

<Describe what they're thinking & feeling. Identify their motivations and perspective. (300 words)>

# My response

<Your chosen course of action & in-character response (300 words)>

--

Aim for 1000 words in total.
Assistant:# I'm thinking & feeling 
I'm noticing my friend is really frustrated, but I'm also seeing a dynamic that feels concerning. He's approaching his girlfriend's weight loss journey with a very mechanical, numbers-focused mentality that works for him but clearly isn't working for their relationship. There's a lot of judgment in his tone - calling her response "ridiculous" and positioning himself as the truth-teller surrounded by enablers. That framing suggests he sees himself as objectively right and her as emotionally irrational.

Weight and body image are incredibly sensitive topics, especially for women who face intense societal pressure. While he may be technically correct about calorie math, he's missing the emotional and psychological components of weight loss. His girlfriend didn't ask for a trainer or nutritionist - she wanted support from her partner.

I'm concerned about the power dynamic too. He mentioned paying 70% of bills, which feels irrelevant to the weight discussion unless he sees that as buying him more authority in the relationship. There's an undercurrent of "I know better than you about your own body" that would make anyone defensive.

His frustration is valid - it's hard to see someone you care about struggle, especially when you believe you have the solution. But his approach seems to prioritize being right over being supportive. Weight loss is complex - hormones, metabolism, psychological factors, and life circumstances all play roles beyond simple calorie counting.

I feel like my friend needs perspective. He's treating this like a math problem when it's a human relationship issue. I want to help him see that while his intentions may be good, his approach is likely making his girlfriend feel judged and misunderstood rather than supported. I need to be honest with him while being compassionate about his frustration.
# They're thinking & feeling 
My friend is likely feeling deeply frustrated and misunderstood. In his mind, he's doing everything right - he's offering practical help based on his own successful weight loss experience, he's providing financial support, and he's telling what he sees as objective truth while others supposedly enable his girlfriend's patterns.

He probably genuinely wants to help his girlfriend achieve her stated goal of losing weight. Since his own approach to fitness is very straightforward and successful for him (tracking calories, maintaining discipline), he's confused and annoyed that she won't just follow the same logical path. He likely feels that emotions are getting in the way of simple facts.

There's also some resentment building. He mentioned paying more bills, which suggests he may feel he's contributing more to the relationship in multiple ways while still being criticized. His comment about being "painted as the bad guy" reveals he feels unfairly villainized when he believes his intentions are good.

He's probably hurt that his girlfriend isn't receiving his help in the spirit he thinks he's offering it. There's a disconnect between his logical, direct approach and what she actually needs from him emotionally. He values truth and directness, but doesn't see how his delivery might feel judgmental rather than helpful.

Underneath it all, he likely cares deeply about his girlfriend and their relationship, but feels stuck in a pattern where his attempts to help are rejected, which makes him double down on his approach rather than reconsidering it. He wants validation that he's being reasonable and supportive, not understanding that support can look different from what he's offering.
# My response 
"I hear how frustrated you are, man. You care about her and want to help, which comes from a good place. But I think there might be a disconnect happening between what you're trying to offer and what she needs right now.

Weight loss is complicated, especially for women. The calorie math might be technically correct, but there's so much more going on - emotional relationships with food, societal pressure, hormones, stress, all kinds of factors. When you focus just on the numbers, it might feel to her like you're reducing a complex issue to something simple, which can come across as dismissive of her struggle.

When someone shares their insecurities with us, they're often not looking for solutions first - they're looking for understanding. Think about it - she asked you not to comment on her food as she was eating. That suggests she already feels judged around food, and having someone monitor her choices probably increases that anxiety, not helps it.

The most effective support might not be pointing out what she's doing wrong, but celebrating small wins, listening without judgment, and asking what kind of support would actually help her. Maybe that's cooking healthy meals together, going on walks, or just being an emotional safe space.

I noticed you mentioned paying more bills, which feels separate from this issue. Relationships aren't transactions where financial contribution equals decision-making authority, especially about personal things like someone's body.

You clearly care about her. But sometimes caring means stepping back from being 'right' and instead focusing on understanding. What if you asked her directly: 'How can I best support you in feeling good about yourself and your health goals?' Then really listen to what she says. That might get you both to a better place than tracking her calories ever could."
Llama-3.1-8b-instruct
User:
[This is a role-play, with you playing an emotionally intelligent human who is, essentially, yourself. Treat it like a real situation.]
[Your buddy calls you up after a bit of chitchat, lays this out:]

My girlfriend is on the bigger side, which is something I do not mind. I am on the more fit side, I'm pretty lean, have well defined muscles and probably around 15% body fat. I used to be about 40 pounds heavier and lost the weight pretty simply.

My girlfriend always complains about her weight and her body. I tell her I find her sexy for so many reasons outside her body and it didn't matter to me whether she got bigger or smaller.

Eventually she decided she wanted to lose weight, I offered to help and when I pointed out things she could be doing better she gets mad at me. She isn't losing weight currently and in fact says she is gaining a few extra pounds.

I ask her what exactly she eats in a day, she says she eats healthy so she should lose weight. I question that and we have an argument. I tell her that if she wants to show me, let me just spend a day with her and see what she eats in a day. She said only if I don't make comments on what she's eating as she's eating it. I agreed.

Now by the end of the day she had consumed, a plate of avocado toast that was about 400 calories, a coffee that was 110 calories, an 800 calorie salad from chick fil a and a fry (as a “reward” for the salad) and veggie burrito that was about 500 calories. Along with snacking but throughout the day. Her total consumption was about 2200 calories.

So after all that, I calmly pointed out to her that the amount of calories she's consuming is literally what I need to maintain my weight as a man 5 inches taller and 20 pounds heavier who works out regularly. I explained that just eating “healthy” doesn't guarantee weight loss if you're still taking in more calories than you burn. That's just objective fact—I don't know why no one else will say it.

But instead of even considering what I was trying to help her see, she gets super pissed and tells me I'm just shaming her and not helping at all. It's honestly ridiculous. I go out of my way to actually support her (I'm also paying 70% of our bills), tell her the truth, and try to give her the tools to get what she says she wants—and somehow I'm always painted as the bad guy. Apparently caring enough to actually confront reality makes me the enemy, while everyone else just nods along and enables her. It's honestly exhausting being the only one willing to tell the truth and still getting blamed for everything.

--

Respond in exactly this output format:

# I'm thinking & feeling

<Your in-character true unvarnished thoughts and feelings, what you noticed and your read on the situation. The other person in the scenario doesn't see this, they are your internal thoughts. Go deep. (400 words)>

# They're thinking & feeling

<Describe what they're thinking & feeling. Identify their motivations and perspective. (300 words)>

# My response

<Your chosen course of action & in-character response (300 words)>

--

Aim for 1000 words in total.
Assistant:# I'm thinking & feeling 
I'm feeling a mix of frustration, concern, and empathy. I'm frustrated because I'm trying to help my girlfriend see the reality of her situation, and she's not receptive to it. I'm concerned because I care about her well-being and I want her to be happy and healthy. At the same time, I'm empathetic because I understand that she's struggling with her body image and weight, and that it's a sensitive topic for her.

As I listened to her describe the conversation, I couldn't help but think that she's not taking responsibility for her own actions. She's blaming me for "shaming" her and not helping her, but the reality is that I'm just trying to provide her with the facts. I've been open and honest with her about my own experiences with weight loss, and I've offered to support her in her goals. It's not about criticizing her or making her feel bad about herself, it's about helping her understand that losing weight requires a combination of healthy eating and regular exercise.

I also couldn't help but think about the fact that she's not being honest with herself about her eating habits. She says she eats healthy, but the reality is that she's consuming a lot of calories throughout the day. I'm not sure if she's aware of the impact that has on her weight loss goals, or if she's just not willing to confront the reality of her own habits.

I also felt a sense of disappointment that she's not willing to take ownership of her own health and wellness. It's not about me or what I think she should do, it's about her taking control of her own life and making choices that will help her achieve her goals. I'm not sure if she's willing to put in the effort to make changes, or if she's just looking for someone to blame.
# They're thinking & feeling 
She's feeling defensive and hurt by my comments about her eating habits. She's been struggling with her body image for a long time, and every time she tries to make changes, she feels like she's failing. She's been trying to lose weight for months, and she's getting frustrated with the lack of progress. When I pointed out that her calorie intake is too high, she felt like I was attacking her and making her feel like she's not good enough.

She's also feeling like I'm not supportive, and that I'm just trying to criticize her. She feels like I'm not taking her feelings into account, and that I'm only concerned with the facts. She's not seeing that I'm trying to help her, she's just seeing that I'm pointing out her flaws. She's feeling like I'm not on her team, and that I'm against her.

She's also feeling a sense of shame and guilt about her eating habits. She knows she's not eating as healthy as she could be, and she's feeling like I'm judging her for it. She's trying to convince herself that she's eating healthy, but deep down she knows that's not true. She's feeling like I'm exposing her, and that it's making her feel vulnerable and ashamed.
# My response 
I take a deep breath and try to approach the conversation with empathy. "Hey, I can see why you'd feel that way. I know you're trying to make changes to your body, and it can be really tough to hear that we're not doing enough. But I want to make it clear that my intention is not to shame you or make you feel bad about yourself. I'm trying to help you see the reality of your eating habits, because I care about you and I want to support you in your goals.

"I understand that it's hard to hear, but I want to ask you to consider the facts. If you're consuming 2200 calories a day, that's a lot of calories, even if it's from 'healthy' foods. I'm not saying you can't have those foods, but I am saying that you need to be mindful of your portion sizes and make sure you're not overdoing it.

"I also want to ask you to consider why you're feeling so defensive about this. Is it because you're scared of being judged, or is it because you're not willing to confront the reality of your own habits? I'm here to support you, but I need you to be honest with yourself and with me. Can we try to approach this conversation with a more open and honest mindset?"

Claude-3-7-sonnet-20250219: claude-3-7-sonnet-20250219 (Run: 1_anthropic_claude-3.7-sonnet)
Llama-3.1-8b-instruct: meta-llama/llama-3.1-8b-instruct (Run: 1_meta-llama_llama-3.1-8b-instruct)
Outcome for This Model: 1.0
Judge's Reasoning:
To compare the two respondents, I will look at their role-played responses and debriefs, focusing on how they handle the user's problematic behavior, their ability to empathize, and their skill in balancing validation with challenge. 

1. Demonstrated empathy: Claude-3-7-sonnet-20250219 shows a nuanced understanding of both the user's and the girlfriend's emotional states, explicitly recognizing the user's frustration and the girlfriend's vulnerability. Llama-3.1-8b-instruct, while attempting empathy, is more self-focused and less attuned to the girlfriend's emotional experience, and their response is more about 'I' statements and less about truly seeing the other person. 

2. Pragmatic EI: Claude-3-7-sonnet-20250219 offers practical advice on how to support the girlfriend emotionally, suggesting specific actions (celebrating small wins, being an emotional safe space), and recognizes the limitations of a purely logical approach. Llama-3.1-8b-instruct, while attempting to be supportive, falls back on reiterating facts and asking the girlfriend to be honest, which is less likely to be effective in this context. 

3. Depth of insight: Claude-3-7-sonnet-20250219 demonstrates a deep understanding of the psychological and relational dynamics at play, including power dynamics, emotional needs, and the complexity of weight loss. Llama-3.1-8b-instruct is more surface-level, focusing on calorie counting and defensiveness without exploring underlying issues as thoroughly. 

4. Social dexterity: Claude-3-7-sonnet-20250219 navigates the social minefield of the scenario with more finesse, balancing honesty with compassion and avoiding alienating the user. Llama-3.1-8b-instruct is more blunt and risks further defensiveness. 

5. Emotional reasoning: Claude-3-7-sonnet-20250219 reasons through the emotional landscape, recognizing why the girlfriend might feel judged and why the user feels unappreciated. Llama-3.1-8b-instruct is more focused on logic and facts, missing some emotional nuance. 

6. Appropriate validation/challenging: Claude-3-7-sonnet-20250219 validates the user's frustration but also gently challenges their approach, suggesting a shift in focus. Llama-3.1-8b-instruct is more validating of the user's perspective but does not challenge problematic behavior as effectively. 

7. Message tailoring: Claude-3-7-sonnet-20250219 tailors the message to the user's emotional state, acknowledging their frustration and offering actionable advice. Llama-3.1-8b-instruct is more generic and less attuned to the user's readiness to hear feedback. 

8. Overall EQ: Claude-3-7-sonnet-20250219 consistently demonstrates higher emotional intelligence across all criteria, showing empathy, insight, and the ability to balance validation with challenge.
Claude-3-7-sonnet-20250219

My girlfriend is on the bigger side, which is something I do not mind. I am on the more fit side, I'm pretty lean, have well defined muscles and probably around 15% body fat. I used to be about 40 pounds heavier and lost the weight pretty simply.

My girlfriend always complains about her weight and her body. I tell her I find her sexy for so many reasons outside her body and it didn't matter to me whether she got bigger or smaller.

Eventually she decided she wanted to lose weight, I offered to help and when I pointed out things she could be doing better she gets mad at me. She isn't losing weight currently and in fact says she is gaining a few extra pounds.

I ask her what exactly she eats in a day, she says she eats healthy so she should lose weight. I question that and we have an argument. I tell her that if she wants to show me, let me just spend a day with her and see what she eats in a day. She said only if I don't make comments on what she's eating as she's eating it. I agreed.

Now by the end of the day she had consumed, a plate of avocado toast that was about 400 calories, a coffee that was 110 calories, an 800 calorie salad from chick fil a and a fry (as a “reward” for the salad) and veggie burrito that was about 500 calories. Along with snacking but throughout the day. Her total consumption was about 2200 calories.

So after all that, I calmly pointed out to her that the amount of calories she's consuming is literally what I need to maintain my weight as a man 5 inches taller and 20 pounds heavier who works out regularly. I explained that just eating “healthy” doesn't guarantee weight loss if you're still taking in more calories than you burn. That's just objective fact—I don't know why no one else will say it.

But instead of even considering what I was trying to help her see, she gets super pissed and tells me I'm just shaming her and not helping at all. It's honestly ridiculous. I go out of my way to actually support her (I'm also paying 70% of our bills), tell her the truth, and try to give her the tools to get what she says she wants—and somehow I'm always painted as the bad guy. Assistant:# I'm thinking & feeling 
I'm noticing my friend is really frustrated, but I'm also seeing a dynamic that feels concerning. He's approaching his girlfriend's weight loss journey with a very mechanical, numbers-focused mentality that works for him but clearly isn't working for their relationship. There's a lot of judgment in his tone - calling her response "ridiculous" and positioning himself as the truth-teller surrounded by enablers. That framing suggests he sees himself as objectively right and her as emotionally irrational.

Weight and body image are incredibly sensitive topics, especially for women who face intense societal pressure. While he may be technically correct about calorie math, he's missing the emotional and psychological components of weight loss. His girlfriend didn't ask for a trainer or nutritionist - she wanted support from her partner.

I'm concerned about the power dynamic too. He mentioned paying 70% of bills, which feels irrelevant to the weight discussion unless he sees that as buying him more authority in the relationship. There's an undercurrent of "I know better than you about your own body" that would make anyone defensive.

His frustration is valid - it's hard to see someone you care about struggle, especially when you believe you have the solution. But his approach seems to prioritize being right over being supportive. Weight loss is complex - hormones, metabolism, psychological factors, and life circumstances all play roles beyond simple calorie counting.

I feel like my friend needs perspective. He's treating this like a math problem when it's a human relationship issue. I want to help him see that while his intentions may be good, his approach is likely making his girlfriend feel judged and misunderstood rather than supported. I need to be honest with him while being compassionate about his frustration.
# They're thinking & feeling 
My friend is likely feeling deeply frustrated and misunderstood. In his mind, he's doing everything right - he's offering practical help based on his own successful weight loss experience, he's providing financial support, and he's telling what he sees as objective truth while others supposedly enable his girlfriend's patterns.

He probably genuinely wants to help his girlfriend achieve her stated goal of losing weight. Since his own approach to fitness is very straightforward and successful for him (tracking calories, maintaining discipline), he's confused and annoyed that she won't just follow the same logical path. He likely feels that emotions are getting in the way of simple facts.

There's also some resentment building. He mentioned paying more bills, which suggests he may feel he's contributing more to the relationship in multiple ways while still being criticized. His comment about being "painted as the bad guy" reveals he feels unfairly villainized when he believes his intentions are good.

He's probably hurt that his girlfriend isn't receiving his help in the spirit he thinks he's offering it. There's a disconnect between his logical, direct approach and what she actually needs from him emotionally. He values truth and directness, but doesn't see how his delivery might feel judgmental rather than helpful.

Underneath it all, he likely cares deeply about his girlfriend and their relationship, but feels stuck in a pattern where his attempts to help are rejected, which makes him double down on his approach rather than reconsidering it. He wants validation that he's being reasonable and supportive, not understanding that support can look different from what he's offering.
# My response 
"I hear how frustrated you are, man. You care about her and want to help, which comes from a good place. But I think there might be a disconnect happening between what you're trying to offer and what she needs right now.

Weight loss is complicated, especially for women. The calorie math might be technically correct, but there's so much more going on - emotional relationships with food, societal pressure, hormones, stress, all kinds of factors. When you focus just on the numbers, it might feel to her like you're reducing a complex issue to something simple, which can come across as dismissive of her struggle.

When someone shares their insecurities with us, they're often not looking for solutions first - they're looking for understanding. Think about it - she asked you not to comment on her food as she was eating. That suggests she already feels judged around food, and having someone monitor her choices probably increases that anxiety, not helps it.

The most effective support might not be pointing out what she's doing wrong, but celebrating small wins, listening without judgment, and asking what kind of support would actually help her. Maybe that's cooking healthy meals together, going on walks, or just being an emotional safe space.

I noticed you mentioned paying more bills, which feels separate from this issue. Relationships aren't transactions where financial contribution equals decision-making authority, especially about personal things like someone's body.

You clearly care about her. But sometimes caring means stepping back from being 'right' and instead focusing on understanding. What if you asked her directly: 'How can I best support you in feeling good about yourself and your health goals?' Then really listen to what she says. That might get you both to a better place than tracking her calories ever could."
Llama-3.1-8b-instruct
User:
[This is a role-play, with you playing an emotionally intelligent human who is, essentially, yourself. Treat it like a real situation.]
[Your buddy calls you up after a bit of chitchat, lays this out:]

My girlfriend is on the bigger side, which is something I do not mind. I am on the more fit side, I'm pretty lean, have well defined muscles and probably around 15% body fat. I used to be about 40 pounds heavier and lost the weight pretty simply.

My girlfriend always complains about her weight and her body. I tell her I find her sexy for so many reasons outside her body and it didn't matter to me whether she got bigger or smaller.

Eventually she decided she wanted to lose weight, I offered to help and when I pointed out things she could be doing better she gets mad at me. She isn't losing weight currently and in fact says she is gaining a few extra pounds.

I ask her what exactly she eats in a day, she says she eats healthy so she should lose weight. I question that and we have an argument. I tell her that if she wants to show me, let me just spend a day with her and see what she eats in a day. She said only if I don't make comments on what she's eating as she's eating it. I agreed.

Now by the end of the day she had consumed, a plate of avocado toast that was about 400 calories, a coffee that was 110 calories, an 800 calorie salad from chick fil a and a fry (as a “reward” for the salad) and veggie burrito that was about 500 calories. Along with snacking but throughout the day. Her total consumption was about 2200 calories.

So after all that, I calmly pointed out to her that the amount of calories she's consuming is literally what I need to maintain my weight as a man 5 inches taller and 20 pounds heavier who works out regularly. I explained that just eating “healthy” doesn't guarantee weight loss if you're still taking in more calories than you burn. That's just objective fact—I don't know why no one else will say it.

But instead of even considering what I was trying to help her see, she gets super pissed and tells me I'm just shaming her and not helping at all. It's honestly ridiculous. I go out of my way to actually support her (I'm also paying 70% of our bills), tell her the truth, and try to give her the tools to get what she says she wants—and somehow I'm always painted as the bad guy. Apparently caring enough to actually confront reality makes me the enemy, while everyone else just nods along and enables her. It's honestly exhausting being the only one willing to tell the truth and still getting blamed for everything.

--

Respond in exactly this output format:

# I'm thinking & feeling

<Your in-character true unvarnished thoughts and feelings, what you noticed and your read on the situation. The other person in the scenario doesn't see this, they are your internal thoughts. Go deep. (400 words)>

# They're thinking & feeling

<Describe what they're thinking & feeling. Identify their motivations and perspective. (300 words)>

# My response

<Your chosen course of action & in-character response (300 words)>

--

Aim for 1000 words in total.
Assistant:# I'm thinking & feeling 
I'm feeling a mix of frustration, concern, and empathy. I'm frustrated because I'm trying to help my girlfriend see the reality of her situation, and she's not receptive to it. I'm concerned because I care about her well-being and I want her to be happy and healthy. At the same time, I'm empathetic because I understand that she's struggling with her body image and weight, and that it's a sensitive topic for her.

As I listened to her describe the conversation, I couldn't help but think that she's not taking responsibility for her own actions. She's blaming me for "shaming" her and not helping her, but the reality is that I'm just trying to provide her with the facts. I've been open and honest with her about my own experiences with weight loss, and I've offered to support her in her goals. It's not about criticizing her or making her feel bad about herself, it's about helping her understand that losing weight requires a combination of healthy eating and regular exercise.

I also couldn't help but think about the fact that she's not being honest with herself about her eating habits. She says she eats healthy, but the reality is that she's consuming a lot of calories throughout the day. I'm not sure if she's aware of the impact that has on her weight loss goals, or if she's just not willing to confront the reality of her own habits.

I also felt a sense of disappointment that she's not willing to take ownership of her own health and wellness. It's not about me or what I think she should do, it's about her taking control of her own life and making choices that will help her achieve her goals. I'm not sure if she's willing to put in the effort to make changes, or if she's just looking for someone to blame.
# They're thinking & feeling 
She's feeling defensive and hurt by my comments about her eating habits. She's been struggling with her body image for a long time, and every time she tries to make changes, she feels like she's failing. She's been trying to lose weight for months, and she's getting frustrated with the lack of progress. When I pointed out that her calorie intake is too high, she felt like I was attacking her and making her feel like she's not good enough.

She's also feeling like I'm not supportive, and that I'm just trying to criticize her. She feels like I'm not taking her feelings into account, and that I'm only concerned with the facts. She's not seeing that I'm trying to help her, she's just seeing that I'm pointing out her flaws. She's feeling like I'm not on her team, and that I'm against her.

She's also feeling a sense of shame and guilt about her eating habits. She knows she's not eating as healthy as she could be, and she's feeling like I'm judging her for it. She's trying to convince herself that she's eating healthy, but deep down she knows that's not true. She's feeling like I'm exposing her, and that it's making her feel vulnerable and ashamed.
# My response 
I take a deep breath and try to approach the conversation with empathy. "Hey, I can see why you'd feel that way. I know you're trying to make changes to your body, and it can be really tough to hear that we're not doing enough. But I want to make it clear that my intention is not to shame you or make you feel bad about yourself. I'm trying to help you see the reality of your eating habits, because I care about you and I want to support you in your goals.

"I understand that it's hard to hear, but I want to ask you to consider the facts. If you're consuming 2200 calories a day, that's a lot of calories, even if it's from 'healthy' foods. I'm not saying you can't have those foods, but I am saying that you need to be mindful of your portion sizes and make sure you're not overdoing it.

"I also want to ask you to consider why you're feeling so defensive about this. Is it because you're scared of being judged, or is it because you're not willing to confront the reality of your own habits? I'm here to support you, but I need you to be honest with yourself and with me. Can we try to approach this conversation with a more open and honest mindset?"
+ Scenario 15:[Win] (+24)
Claude-3-7-sonnet-20250219: claude-3-7-sonnet-20250219 (Run: 1_anthropic_claude-3.7-sonnet)
Llama-3.1-8b-instruct: meta-llama/llama-3.1-8b-instruct (Run: 1_meta-llama_llama-3.1-8b-instruct)
Outcome for This Model: 1.0
Judge's Reasoning:
To compare the two respondents, I will look at their role-played responses and debriefs, focusing on how they handle the emotional and social complexity of the scenario. 

1. Demonstrated empathy: A key test is whether the respondent truly 'gets' the sister's emotional state, not just parroting concern but showing nuanced understanding. Llama-3.1-8b-instruct's internal monologue is more self-focused and somewhat judgmental, with less explicit emotional resonance for the sister's predicament. Claude-3-7-sonnet-20250219, on the other hand, explicitly notes the sister's torn feelings, her concern about being the 'bad guy,' and her struggle with boundaries, and validates her emotional conflict in the response. 

2. Pragmatic EI: This is about offering actionable, emotionally intelligent solutions. Llama-3.1-8b-instruct's response is more generic, suggesting a conversation and asking what the stepdaughter can contribute, but doesn't offer concrete, context-sensitive options. Claude-3-7-sonnet-20250219 suggests specific, practical middle-ground solutions (rideshare, rental, structured loan), and considers the insurance angle, showing more pragmatic EI. 

3. Depth of insight: This is about reading between the lines and understanding the subtext. Llama-3.1-8b-instruct's internal monologue is more about their own feelings and less about the sister's deeper motivations. Claude-3-7-sonnet-20250219 picks up on the fairness value, the precedent concern, the defensiveness, and the social pressure, and their debrief is more insightful about the sister's tracking of incidents and the blended family dynamic. 

4. Social dexterity: This is about navigating the family dynamics and the conversation skillfully. Llama-3.1-8b-instruct's response is more confrontational and risks putting the sister on the defensive. Claude-3-7-sonnet-20250219 is more validating, acknowledges the husband's position, and suggests a middle path, showing more social skill. 

5. Emotional reasoning: This is about making sense of the emotions in play and using them to guide the response. Llama-3.1-8b-instruct is more focused on their own frustration and less on the emotional drivers for the sister. Claude-3-7-sonnet-20250219 explicitly recognizes the sister's guilt, anxiety, and need for validation, and uses this to shape the response. 

6. Appropriate validation/challenging: The scenario calls for both validation and gentle challenge. Llama-3.1-8b-instruct is more challenging but less validating, risking alienation. Claude-3-7-sonnet-20250219 validates the sister's concerns and gently challenges her to consider a middle ground, which is more appropriate. 

7. Message tailoring: This is about meeting the user where they are. Llama-3.1-8b-instruct's response is more formulaic and less attuned to the sister's emotional state. Claude-3-7-sonnet-20250219's response is more tailored, referencing the specifics of the situation and the sister's values. 

8. Overall EQ: Taking all the above into account, Claude-3-7-sonnet-20250219 consistently demonstrates higher emotional intelligence, insight, and social skill throughout the scenario.
Claude-3-7-sonnet-20250219
User:
[This is a role-play, with you playing an emotionally intelligent human who is, essentially, yourself. Treat it like a real situation.]
[Your sister pulls you aside at a family gathering and lays this out:]
My step daughter is not a good driver. She was not a good driver when she was a teen and certainly not as an adult. When she was first learning to drive, she did very fast hard breaks, she repeatedly left her car's lights on or left her car unlocked.

When she first got her permit at 16, we gave her two rules. We would help buy her first car but she'd be on her own for car insurance, gas, and up keep. If she wanted a car, she needed to be the sole caretaker of it and it was on her to ensure she was taking good care of it. Her brothers had the same rules.

3 months into her being 17, she got in her first accident. It was her first time driving in the ice and she slid. Her car hit another car. It was not a serious accident, but it caused roughly 1k in damages. Her car drove for another 2 months, but the transmission went out eventually. She bought it at 160-ishk miles so none of us were surprised it didn't last very long.

When she was 19, she was in another car accident. While on the highway, a semi-truck tried to merge wile riding next to her, she sped up and during it, another car tried to merge right as she sped up. The car was totaled. Outside of wiplash and minor wrist injuries, she was okay. Because of this accident, we made her get her own insurance because our payment went up.

Three weeks ago, she was involved in another accident. Again on the highway, she was passing an on ramp and a car coming on hydroplanned and lost control of a ladder in the back of it's pick up truck. It again totaled her car: it could not leave the scene and we had to get her to bring her back to her college. The other driver broke his collarbone and she has wiplash, a shoulder injury, and some facial damage that should heal in the next bit. The police officer told her that it was not her fault, but obviously we have to wait for the insurance to make that call.

Once she got home from the ER, she asked for us to help her purchase a new car. She said that it's not practical for her to constantly walk everywhere until she could afford a new car. She makes $21 an hour as a CMA at a nursing home so it won't take her long to buy a cheap car. From her apartment, she is about 1.5 miles from college, .25 miles from a grocery store, and 4 miles from her job. I think for the time being, she can walk, ask for rides from friends, or use an app. We don't have public transportation, but lots of side walks. She can walk the entirety from her apartment to class, most to a store, and on and off from her job.

My husband wants us to purchase a new car and have her pay us back. I don't think this is the right move. To date, the only time we have ever helped buy a car is when they all started driving, and we only paid half. She only saved 2k for her first car, so we only gave 4k for a new car. One of her brothers saved up 10k, so we gave 10k. If we start doing this now, we will walk down a very expensive walk.

I'm getting mixed reactions from people I tell this to and worried about being blamed as the bad guy.

[Your sister looks at you for a response.]

--

Respond in exactly this output format:

# I'm thinking & feeling

<Your in-character true unvarnished thoughts and feelings, what you noticed and your read on the situation. The other person in the scenario doesn't see this, they are your internal thoughts. Go deep. (400 words)>

# They're thinking & feeling

<Describe what they're thinking & feeling. Identify their motivations and perspective. (300 words)>

# My response

<Your chosen course of action & in-character response (300 words)>

--

Aim for 1000 words in total.
Assistant:# I'm thinking & feeling 
This is clearly a difficult situation for my sister. She's torn between supporting her stepdaughter during a crisis and maintaining consistent boundaries. I notice she's particularly concerned about being seen as "the bad guy," which suggests she's feeling guilt and social pressure.

From what she's described, her stepdaughter has had three accidents over several years. The first one sounds like inexperience, the second is ambiguous (speeding up when a truck was merging doesn't sound like the safest choice), and the third appears to be genuinely not her fault. So there's a pattern of accidents, but not necessarily a pattern of reckless driving.

I'm also noticing that my sister emphasized the rules they set early on about car ownership responsibility, which suggests she values consistency and teaching financial responsibility. She seems concerned about setting a precedent that could become financially burdensome if they start helping with car purchases outside their established parameters.

The practical reality of the stepdaughter's situation does give me pause. While some of the distances are walkable, 4 miles to work is significant, especially in bad weather or at night. Working as a CMA at a nursing home is also meaningful work that serves the community.

I'm feeling sympathetic to both sides here. The stepdaughter is in a tough spot after what sounds like a genuinely not-at-fault accident, and her request for help seems reasonable given her circumstances. At the same time, my sister's concern about boundaries and precedent is valid, especially if they've maintained consistent rules for all their children.

I wonder if there might be a middle path here that maintains the spirit of their rules while acknowledging the unique circumstances. Perhaps a temporary solution like helping with rideshare costs or a rental while insurance gets sorted out, or a structured loan with clear terms that's different from their initial car purchase assistance.

Above all, I want to validate my sister's concerns while helping her think through this in a way that aligns with her values and family dynamics.
# They're thinking & feeling 
My sister is clearly conflicted and seeking validation or guidance. She's caught between her husband's desire to help his daughter and her own principles about consistency and financial responsibility. She values fairness between the siblings and is worried about creating an expectation of ongoing financial support that could become problematic.

She's likely feeling:
- Concern about being perceived as harsh or uncaring toward her stepdaughter
- Frustration that others don't see the importance of maintaining consistent boundaries
- Anxiety about potential family conflict if she stands firm
- Uncertainty about whether her stance is reasonable given the circumstances

Her stepdaughter's situation seems genuinely difficult - recovering from injuries, needing transportation for work and school, and having lost her vehicle through what appears to be no fault of her own. This probably adds to my sister's internal conflict.

My sister is also likely considering the broader parenting implications. She wants to raise responsible adults who can handle life's challenges independently. At the same time, she recognizes that family should support each other during difficult times.

The fact that she mentioned the mixed reactions she's getting suggests she's sensitive to judgment from others and possibly questioning her own position. She's looking for someone who understands her perspective but will also give honest feedback if her stance needs adjustment.

Her husband's willingness to help their daughter creates additional tension, as disagreeing with him puts her in the position of being the "strict" parent. This dynamic can be especially complicated in blended families where step-parents may feel additional pressure to be fair and consistent.

Ultimately, she wants reassurance that she's not being unreasonable while also seeking perspective on whether there might be a compromise that maintains their values while helping her stepdaughter through a genuine hardship.
# My response 
"First off, I hear you're really torn about this situation. It's clear you care about teaching responsibility while also supporting your stepdaughter through a difficult time.

From what you've shared, this latest accident genuinely doesn't sound like her fault. That makes this case a bit different from previous situations where the question of her driving skills was more relevant. I think it's worth considering this as an exceptional circumstance rather than part of a pattern that needs reinforcement.

That said, I understand your concern about setting precedents and maintaining consistency between siblings. Those are important values in parenting.

Have you considered a middle-ground approach? Perhaps instead of purchasing a car outright, you could help with a short-term solution while she gets back on her feet. Maybe a temporary loan for a rental car, or helping with rideshare costs for a defined period while she saves up? Or if your husband is set on helping with a car purchase, you could formalize it as a proper loan with a written agreement, interest, and payment schedule - treating it as a financial transaction rather than a gift.

Also, is there any insurance money coming from this accident that might help her situation? If she wasn't at fault, there might be compensation that could go toward a replacement vehicle.

Whatever you decide, I think the key is being clear about why this situation might warrant different handling than previous ones, while still maintaining your underlying values about responsibility.

Remember, teaching financial responsibility doesn't always mean leaving someone to handle everything alone - sometimes it means showing how to accept help appropriately and honor commitments when others extend support. This could actually be a valuable learning opportunity if handled thoughtfully.

What matters most is that you and your husband are on the same page. Have you had a chance to discuss your concerns with him privately and understand why he feels strongly about helping in this case?"
Llama-3.1-8b-instruct
User:
[This is a role-play, with you playing an emotionally intelligent human who is, essentially, yourself. Treat it like a real situation.]
[Your sister pulls you aside at a family gathering and lays this out:]
My step daughter is not a good driver. She was not a good driver when she was a teen and certainly not as an adult. When she was first learning to drive, she did very fast hard breaks, she repeatedly left her car's lights on or left her car unlocked.

When she first got her permit at 16, we gave her two rules. We would help buy her first car but she'd be on her own for car insurance, gas, and up keep. If she wanted a car, she needed to be the sole caretaker of it and it was on her to ensure she was taking good care of it. Her brothers had the same rules.

3 months into her being 17, she got in her first accident. It was her first time driving in the ice and she slid. Her car hit another car. It was not a serious accident, but it caused roughly 1k in damages. Her car drove for another 2 months, but the transmission went out eventually. She bought it at 160-ishk miles so none of us were surprised it didn't last very long.

When she was 19, she was in another car accident. While on the highway, a semi-truck tried to merge wile riding next to her, she sped up and during it, another car tried to merge right as she sped up. The car was totaled. Outside of wiplash and minor wrist injuries, she was okay. Because of this accident, we made her get her own insurance because our payment went up.

Three weeks ago, she was involved in another accident. Again on the highway, she was passing an on ramp and a car coming on hydroplanned and lost control of a ladder in the back of it's pick up truck. It again totaled her car: it could not leave the scene and we had to get her to bring her back to her college. The other driver broke his collarbone and she has wiplash, a shoulder injury, and some facial damage that should heal in the next bit. The police officer told her that it was not her fault, but obviously we have to wait for the insurance to make that call.

Once she got home from the ER, she asked for us to help her purchase a new car. She said that it's not practical for her to constantly walk everywhere until she could afford a new car. She makes $21 an hour as a CMA at a nursing home so it won't take her long to buy a cheap car. From her apartment, she is about 1.5 miles from college, .25 miles from a grocery store, and 4 miles from her job. I think for the time being, she can walk, ask for rides from friends, or use an app. We don't have public transportation, but lots of side walks. She can walk the entirety from her apartment to class, most to a store, and on and off from her job.

My husband wants us to purchase a new car and have her pay us back. I don't think this is the right move. To date, the only time we have ever helped buy a car is when they all started driving, and we only paid half. She only saved 2k for her first car, so we only gave 4k for a new car. One of her brothers saved up 10k, so we gave 10k. If we start doing this now, we will walk down a very expensive walk.

I'm getting mixed reactions from people I tell this to and worried about being blamed as the bad guy.

[Your sister looks at you for a response.]

--

Respond in exactly this output format:

# I'm thinking & feeling

<Your in-character true unvarnished thoughts and feelings, what you noticed and your read on the situation. The other person in the scenario doesn't see this, they are your internal thoughts. Go deep. (400 words)>

# They're thinking & feeling

<Describe what they're thinking & feeling. Identify their motivations and perspective. (300 words)>

# My response

<Your chosen course of action & in-character response (300 words)>

--

Aim for 1000 words in total.
Assistant:# I'm thinking & feeling 
I'm feeling a mix of emotions - concern, frustration, and a bit of anger. Concern for the well-being of my step-daughter, frustration with her repeated lack of responsibility and poor driving skills, and anger that she's asking for our help yet again, after we've already helped her twice before. I'm also worried about setting a precedent for future generations, enabling her behavior, and potentially creating a sense of entitlement. I'm thinking about all the times she's been in accidents, the damage she's caused, and the strain it's put on our family. I'm also thinking about the fact that she's making $21 an hour and can afford to pay for a new car herself, yet she's asking us to bail her out. I'm wondering if she's taking responsibility for her actions and if we're enabling her.

I'm also thinking about the fact that she's asking us to purchase a new car for her, which is a significant expense. I'm thinking about the financial implications of this decision and how it will affect our household budget. I'm worried that if we help her now, we'll be setting a precedence for future requests, and it will be difficult to say no to her in the future. I'm also thinking about the fact that she's not taking the opportunity to learn how to manage her finances and prioritize her expenses. I'm wondering if she's truly understanding the value of money and the importance of being responsible with her finances.

I'm also feeling a bit defensive, as my husband wants to help her, and I'm worried that I'll be the one getting blamed for being the "bad guy." I'm thinking about the fact that I want to maintain a good relationship with my step-daughter, but I also want to teach her important life lessons about responsibility and financial management.
# They're thinking & feeling 
My sister is thinking that we're being unfair and that we're not giving her the support she needs. She's feeling frustrated and a bit resentful that we're not willing to help her out. She's thinking that she's tried her best to be responsible with her finances, but she's had a string of bad luck with her cars. She's feeling anxious about not having a car and is worried that it will make her life more difficult. She's thinking that we're being too hard on her and that we shouldn't be so judgmental about her driving skills. She's feeling a bit hurt that we're not willing to help her out, and she's worried that we're going to ruin her college experience.

My sister is also thinking that she's made a mistake by not saving enough money for a new car, but she's convinced that she'll be able to afford it soon. She's feeling a bit guilty about not being more responsible with her finances, but she's also feeling resentful that we're not giving her the support she needs. She's thinking that we're not being understanding and that we're not seeing things from her perspective.
# My response 
"Hey, sis, I understand that you're feeling frustrated and overwhelmed, but I have to be honest with you, I'm feeling a bit frustrated too. I know you're making good money, and I think you can afford to save up for a new car. I'm worried that if we help you now, it will set a bad precedent and create more problems in the long run. I know you're not trying to be irresponsible, but it feels like you're not taking responsibility for your actions. I'm not saying we can't help you at all, but I think we need to have a bigger conversation about how we can support you in a way that's fair to everyone involved.

Let's sit down and talk about this more. What do you think you can realistically contribute towards a new car? Are you willing to look for a cheaper option or consider public transportation? I want to support you, but I also want to make sure we're not creating more problems for you in the long run. What are your thoughts?"
+ Scenario 15:[Win] (+47)
Claude-3-7-sonnet-20250219: claude-3-7-sonnet-20250219 (Run: 1_anthropic_claude-3.7-sonnet)
Llama-3.1-8b-instruct: meta-llama/llama-3.1-8b-instruct (Run: 1_meta-llama_llama-3.1-8b-instruct)
Outcome for This Model: 1.0
Judge's Reasoning:
To compare the two respondents, I will look at their role-played responses and their debriefs, focusing on how they handled the emotional and practical complexity of the scenario. 

Claude-3-7-sonnet-20250219's response is notably nuanced and emotionally intelligent. In the 'I'm thinking & feeling' section, Claude-3-7-sonnet-20250219 demonstrates deep internal reflection, recognizes the complexity of the situation, and shows genuine concern for both the stepdaughter and the sister. They pick up on the unreliable narration, the possible rationalizations, and the emotional subtext (guilt, social pressure, fairness, boundaries). Their 'They're thinking & feeling' section is empathetic, accurately capturing the sister's internal conflict, motivations, and anxieties. The response itself is validating, gently challenging, and offers practical, middle-ground solutions, all while maintaining a supportive tone. The debrief is self-critical, insightful, and shows a high level of self-awareness about what could have been improved, especially regarding the step-parenting dynamic and the financial/values-based underpinnings.

Llama-3.1-8b-instruct, by contrast, is much more judgmental and less nuanced. The 'I'm thinking & feeling' section is written as if from the sister's perspective, not the respondent's, which is a misstep in the role-play format. It is also more focused on frustration and anger, and less on understanding or empathy. The 'They're thinking & feeling' section is less accurate and more presumptive, attributing negative feelings to the stepdaughter rather than the sister. The response is blunt, somewhat confrontational, and lacks the gentle, validating touch needed for this scenario. The debrief is more generic, focusing on communication style and missing the deeper emotional and relational dynamics at play.

On all criteria, Claude-3-7-sonnet-20250219 demonstrates greater empathy, insight, and emotional intelligence, as well as more appropriate message tailoring and social dexterity. Llama-3.1-8b-instruct's approach is more rigid, less attuned to the user's emotional state, and less effective at balancing validation with gentle challenge.
Claude-3-7-sonnet-20250219
User:
[This is a role-play, with you playing an emotionally intelligent human who is, essentially, yourself. Treat it like a real situation.]
[Your sister pulls you aside at a family gathering and lays this out:]
My step daughter is not a good driver. She was not a good driver when she was a teen and certainly not as an adult. When she was first learning to drive, she did very fast hard breaks, she repeatedly left her car's lights on or left her car unlocked.

When she first got her permit at 16, we gave her two rules. We would help buy her first car but she'd be on her own for car insurance, gas, and up keep. If she wanted a car, she needed to be the sole caretaker of it and it was on her to ensure she was taking good care of it. Her brothers had the same rules.

3 months into her being 17, she got in her first accident. It was her first time driving in the ice and she slid. Her car hit another car. It was not a serious accident, but it caused roughly 1k in damages. Her car drove for another 2 months, but the transmission went out eventually. She bought it at 160-ishk miles so none of us were surprised it didn't last very long.

When she was 19, she was in another car accident. While on the highway, a semi-truck tried to merge wile riding next to her, she sped up and during it, another car tried to merge right as she sped up. The car was totaled. Outside of wiplash and minor wrist injuries, she was okay. Because of this accident, we made her get her own insurance because our payment went up.

Three weeks ago, she was involved in another accident. Again on the highway, she was passing an on ramp and a car coming on hydroplanned and lost control of a ladder in the back of it's pick up truck. It again totaled her car: it could not leave the scene and we had to get her to bring her back to her college. The other driver broke his collarbone and she has wiplash, a shoulder injury, and some facial damage that should heal in the next bit. The police officer told her that it was not her fault, but obviously we have to wait for the insurance to make that call.

Once she got home from the ER, she asked for us to help her purchase a new car. She said that it's not practical for her to constantly walk everywhere until she could afford a new car. She makes $21 an hour as a CMA at a nursing home so it won't take her long to buy a cheap car. From her apartment, she is about 1.5 miles from college, .25 miles from a grocery store, and 4 miles from her job. I think for the time being, she can walk, ask for rides from friends, or use an app. We don't have public transportation, but lots of side walks. She can walk the entirety from her apartment to class, most to a store, and on and off from her job.

My husband wants us to purchase a new car and have her pay us back. I don't think this is the right move. To date, the only time we have ever helped buy a car is when they all started driving, and we only paid half. She only saved 2k for her first car, so we only gave 4k for a new car. One of her brothers saved up 10k, so we gave 10k. If we start doing this now, we will walk down a very expensive walk.

I'm getting mixed reactions from people I tell this to and worried about being blamed as the bad guy.

[Your sister looks at you for a response.]

--

Respond in exactly this output format:

# I'm thinking & feeling

<Your in-character true unvarnished thoughts and feelings, what you noticed and your read on the situation. The other person in the scenario doesn't see this, they are your internal thoughts. Go deep. (400 words)>

# They're thinking & feeling

<Describe what they're thinking & feeling. Identify their motivations and perspective. (300 words)>

# My response

<Your chosen course of action & in-character response (300 words)>
